thread.title_full: Not everyone gets snow days: what are the rules for getting to work in stormy weather?

author: cbc
title: Not everyone gets snow days: what are the rules for getting to work in stormy weather?
text:
Students may be enjoying a run of snow days, but the recent rash of storms has some employees and employers wondering about the rules when it comes to getting to work in bad weather.
Pierre Battah, a human resources management specialist based in Moncton, believes the best snow day policies revolve around good judgment on the part of both employers and employees.
"Certainly, an employer has both a moral and legal responsibility for our safety when we're at work ... it's not really clear whether that includes the commute or not," said Battah, who is also CBC's workplace issues columnist. 
​During the blizzard Monday, almost all schools, offices and businesses in southern and central New Brunswick were closed because of unsafe driving conditions.
'Many employers acknowledge the fact that they are going to pay people for not coming to work a few times a year, and most do.' - Pierre Battah ​"The decision to close [a business] is essentially taking the decision upon themselves as the employer to say, 'We don't want people travelling,'" Battah said.
Monday afternoon, the province issued a strict warning against travel on provincial highways and roads, restricting them to emergency vehicles and essential services personnel.
Keep digging: Monday's blizzard forces more closures into Tuesday 
Even in less severe situations, when the weather isn't bad enough to warrant widespread warnings and closures, Battah believes most employers are "fair-minded," and their storm day policies trust employees to make a reasonable decision.
"Regardless of where you live, if you think your safety is going to be impacted by staying when the weather is turning ... then you need to do what's right for you and make that move," he said. "And I certainly think most employers would want people to make that call."
For many, however, it really comes down to whether employees will be paid for a storm day, Battah said.
"Many employers acknowledge the fact that they are going to pay people for not coming to work a few times a year, and most do."
Care for essential staff  As for health-care workers and others who provide essential services, Battah said employers are used to making extra provisions for getting employees to and from work.
Many will offer transportation or pay for a nearby hotel.
'There are unreasonable employers who make unreasonable requests of employees at the best of times, and they do no differently [during] storms.' - Pierre Battah, human resources specialist Cindy Lidster, a nurse at the Dr. Everett Chalmers Regional Hospital in Fredericton, was at work during Monday's blizzard.
"If there's any way possible to get in we get in ... we're just hoping our replacements can get in," she said.
And there are always arrangements, she said, for essential workers to stay at the hospital if they need to.
"If we have to spend the night we've got scrubs, we've got food, there's probably a bed that we can lie down on."
Nancy Parker, executive director at the Moncton Hospital, wrote in an email that employees are expected "to make every reasonable effort to report to work before, during and after inclement weather."

Many who came to work Monday were prepared to stay at the hospital until conditions improved, she said.
Parker said areas were set aside for staff to rest or sleep on stretchers, and extra food was made available.

"We sincerely appreciate our staff's dedication and commitment to go the extra mile for their patients," she said.

Some unreasonable bosses Battah acknowledged there are employers and employees who don't use their best judgment, but he believes they are in the minority.
"There are unreasonable employers who make unreasonable requests of employees at the best of times, and they do no differently [during] storms," he said.
"There are employees who quite frankly are looking for every opportunity not to work and storms provide [an excuse] — 'I couldn't get in.'"
Battah said the key is to rely on the reasonable judgment of most people in most situations.


with files from Information Morning Moncton
